text: I've often seen this happening in companies that don't understand the value of content. Are you able to pull any metrics that demonstrate the actual value you're providing in MQLs, leads, or best of all, revenue? If you can make a case that your time is better spent doing X than Y, or that when other team members jump in and do stuff without consulting you it can negatively impact any of those things, you'll have a better chance of being heard.

text: I have certainly advised content marketers I mentor to decline to move forward in an interview process because the test assignment is unreasonable or clearly designed to squeeze ideas out of candidates that will then be used later. I realize not everyone feels they are in the position to do so, but if your spidey senses are tingling it’s probably for a good reason!

elements.text: I have certainly advised content marketers I mentor to decline to move forward in an interview process because the test assignment is unreasonable or clearly designed to squeeze ideas out of candidates that will then be used later. text: If you really want to pursue the opportunity, but you feel the assignment is unreasonable, I think it’s fair to say, “I expect to get paid to do this level of work and my freelance rate is $X”.

elements.text: If you really want to pursue the opportunity, but you feel the assignment is unreasonable, I think it’s fair to say, “I expect to get paid to do this level of work and my freelance rate is $X”.

text:
Hello Superpath community!

We have a new "Dear Superpath" question. This is a way for folks to ask anonymous questions. 

Career stage: junior (1-3 years of experience)

"Hi all,

sorry that this Q is long and possibly sad sounding. I'm looking for advice on disclosing mental illness in the workplace. Or just making it work without disclosure. 

Context is that when things last got severe, after coming to terms with my declining performance, I cited "health reasons" and took an extended leave of absence. That's too extreme a measure! Got a new treatment plan which has been a tremendous help since, but it's still early and symptoms flare up often. 

Realistically, are there any accommodations or considerations to ask for? Is it ever useful to mention, particularly in the context of freelance/contract arrangements?  

This has hampered my career since the beginning & it's something I'll continue to struggle with. So I'd be grateful to hear your advice or experiences. Thanks everyone. "

i’ve definitely had to keep my eye open for predatory interview practices for writers.

I’ve encountered at least two situations where the application process is a thinly-veiled attempt to get writers to produce free content.

anyone who asks me to write for free because they want to “see my voice,” i show them my portfolio because that’s what samples are for

text: during the times where i went above and beyond on an application-related project, it was usually in spite of instructions telling me “don’t spend more than 2 hours on this, we only want to get a sense of how you think”
